J	O'Connor, C				O'Connor, C			The [dynamic and processual] significance of race: Re-articulating the promise of Wilson's macro-historical framework	ETHNIC AND RACIAL STUDIES			English	Article						race; social class; education; African American; status attainments	EDUCATION	Referencing a qualitative study of how three age cohorts of African American women negotiated the constraints to college completion, this essay will re-articulate the promise of the macro-historical framework Wilson (1980 2nd edn) put forward in the The Declining Significance of Race. The women's life stories convey that while race might have declined in significance with regard to women's chances of making it through college, it maintained heightened significance in relation to the processes by which they 'made it'. In accordance with the presumptions of Wilson's macro-historical framework, the character of these race-related processes shifted in response to the historically bound and college specific representations of structured opportunities and constraints. These findings suggest that rather than mire our selves in debates over whether race is declining in significance or not, we should treat race as a multivalenced phenomenon in order to register how its significance is differentially bound to time, place and the focus of analysis (i.e., the probability versus the process of achieving particular social outcomes). J	Venkatesh, SA				Venkatesh, SA			Whither the 'socially isolated' city?	ETHNIC AND RACIAL STUDIES			English	Article						social isolation; ghetto; urban ethnography; the state; urban poor; social ecology		This article analyses William J. Wilson's use of the concept of social isolation in studying the urban poor. It traces the origins of Wilson's use of the concept in human ecology, focusing upon critical aspects of the 'socially isolated' city and its influence upon ethnographies of the urban poor. His particular focus is upon the interaction of the poor with the mainstream. While Wilson places considerable emphasis upon the role of the state, those appropriating his concept have not adequately incorporated government institutions and discourse into their analyses of culture and practice. J	Banton, M				Banton, M			Discarding Park's axiom	ETHNIC AND RACIAL STUDIES			English	Article						collective action : ethnicity; Hindutva; human rights; Park; race; social construct		Ethnic and racial studies fail to link up well with mainstream sociology if then assume that their subject matter is defined by the social constructs of ethnicity and race. Hindu nationalism cultivates other social constructs, yet recent studies of this movement show that sociologically it has much in common with ethnic and racial movements. The theory of collective action offers the most promising prospect for the analysis of such commonalities on a global scale. J	Martiniello, M				Martiniello, M			Researching and teaching in the field of ethnic and racial studies: a view from continental Europe	ETHNIC AND RACIAL STUDIES			English	Article						ethnicity; migration; diversity; teaching; research		In the first part of the article, I make a few general comments inspired by the reading of Banton's article. I claim that the field of ethnic and racial studies is often dominated by an "Anglo-Americentric" vision that leads to a negation of the variety of approaches to ethnic and racial studies throughout the world. I claim that a process of "decentration" is necessary in order to foster the diversity in our field. In the second part of the article, I make specific comments inspired by my experience as researcher and teacher in a fragmented society such as Belgium. One conclusion is that our teaching has to be contextualized in order to avoid misunderstandings and the reproduction of inadequate conceptions and confusions about ethnic and racial issues among our students.	Univ Liege, Fac Droit, Dept Sci Polit, Ctr Etud Ethic & Migrat, B-4000 Liege, Sart Tilman, Belgium	University of Liege	Martiniello, M (corresponding author), Univ Liege, Fac Droit, Dept Sci Polit, Ctr Etud Ethic & Migrat, Batiment 31,Boite 38,Blvd Rectorat 7, B-4000 Liege, Sart Tilman, Belgium. J	Murji, K				Murji, K			Sociology and the teaching of ethnic and racial studies	ETHNIC AND RACIAL STUDIES			English	Article						pedagogy; textbooks; disciplinarity; society; comparative method		Surveys and other explorations of the teaching of ethnic and racial studies have occurred over three decades in the UK, mostly within sociology. The findings of one recent survey are discussed, along with an examination of sociology textbooks, and used to argue that the content of teaching is both more and less diverse than Michael Banton indicates, and that his account underplays the impact of audit and scrutiny exercises in higher education. This article goes on to argue that many aspects of ethnic and racial studies transcend the boundaries of sociology and other disciplines, and to use Banton's call for comparison as a launch pad to reflect on history of the discipline of sociology and how such reflections can be used to think otherwise about how we teach ethnicity and racism.
